item.title: Performance vs Trust
item.description: Author: Simon Sinek URL: https://youtu.be/kJdXjtSnZTI Businesses are good at measuring performance, but bad at measuring trustworthiness. The Navy Seals think of people in a Performance vs Trust matrix. Ideally you want the high performance, high trust individual, but if you can’t have that person you should value high trust over high performing.
item.content:encoded:
Author: Simon Sinek URL: ¬†https://youtu.be/kJdXjtSnZTI

Businesses are good at measuring performance, but bad at measuring trustworthiness. The Navy Seals think of people in a Performance vs Trust matrix. Ideally you want the high performance, high trust individual, but if you can’t have that person you should value high trust over high performing. The high performing, low trust person is toxic to your team. Medium performance individuals can be taught.

item.title: Escaping video game addiction Cam Adair at TEDxBoulder
item.description: Escaping video game addiction Cam Adair at TEDxBoulder Author: URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EHmC2D0_Hdg Key reasons people play video games They are a temporary escape They are social They are a challenge They demonstrate constant measurable growth If you are struggling with Video Game Addiction look for ways to get what you are getting out of those video games through other sources.
item.content:encoded:
Escaping video game addiction Cam Adair at TEDxBoulder

Author: URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EHmC2D0_Hdg

Key reasons people play video games

  1. They are a temporary escape
  2. They are social
  3. They are a challenge
  4. They demonstrate constant measurable growth

If you are struggling with Video Game Addiction look for ways to get what you are getting out of those video games through other sources.

item.title: The Tickler File
item.description: Author: David Allen URL: https://gettingthingsdone.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/2016-Tickler-File-.pdf The Tickler File is an organizational tool which can be used to simplify the tracking of date-related items and to manage work flow. It works well as an adjunct to personal planners and calendars, allowing them to be used for streamlined focus on items that require on-going review and access.
item.content:encoded:
Author: David Allen URL: https://gettingthingsdone.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/2016-Tickler-File-.pdf

The Tickler File is an organizational tool which can be used to simplify the tracking of date-related items and to manage work flow. It works well as an adjunct to personal planners and calendars, allowing them to be used for streamlined focus on items that require on-going review and access. The Tickler is also referred to as ‚Äúperpetual file,‚Äù ‚Äúbring-forward file,‚Äù ‚Äúfollow-up file,‚Äù or ‚Äúsuspense file.‚Äù

If you want to be reminded to handle something in the future, but don‚Äôt want or need to think about it until then, it can be ‚Äútickled‚Äù to show up exactly on the day or month you‚Äôd like to see it again.

Slice of life: some real things in my tickler file‚ÄîDA

  • Amtrak ticket for the day I need it

What I’ve been building in TickTick with Routines is effectively a digital tickler file

Get ideas out of your head

item.title: The Dash Plus System
item.description: Author: Patrick Rhone URL: https://patrickrhone.com/dashplus/ Capture Tools Analog Handwritten Daily Notes Tools for thought (Dash): Undone Action Item ‚Äî Individual items (action items and ideas) are marked with a dash preceding them.
item.content:encoded:
Author: Patrick Rhone URL: https://patrickrhone.com/dashplus/

Capture Tools Analog Handwritten Daily Notes Tools for thought

(Dash): Undone Action Item ‚Äî Individual items (action items and ideas) are marked with a dash preceding them. All items, no matter what they are, are therefore treated as items to be processed.

(Plus): Done Action Item ‚Äî If the item is an action item (todo), when the item is complete, a vertical line is drawn through the ‚Äúdash‚Äù thus making it resemble a ‚Äúplus‚Äù. This makes the dashed items stand out quite well despite the fact that the same color pen or pencil may be used.

(Right Arrow): Waiting ‚Äì (i.e. for another action) ‚Äî Drawing an arrow pointing to the the item denotes that it is something that is waiting on another action to happen or deliverable.

(Left Arrow): Delegated ‚Äî Drawing an arrow pointing to the left of the item denotes that it has been delegated (with a note to whom and the date) .

(Triangle): Data Point ‚Äî Turning the dash into a triangle denotes a data point (a fact or figure you wish to remember for instance).

(Circle) ‚Äî A circle around any of the above means that it has been carried forward, moved to another list or otherwise changed status ‚Äì i.e. a ‚ÄúWaiting‚Äù item has now become an Action Item elsewhere (with a note about where that item has gone).

item.title: Don‚Äôt Go Entirely Paperless
item.description: Author: Curtis Mchale URL: https://curtismchale.ca/2021/12/28/dont-go-entirely-paperless/ In this article Curtis comments on the Guilt generated by Task Managers when incomplete tasks move forward. He hypothesizes that not living up to the ideal version of yourself is the source of this guilt.
item.content:encoded:
Author: Curtis Mchale URL: https://curtismchale.ca/2021/12/28/dont-go-entirely-paperless/

In this article Curtis comments on the Guilt generated by Task Managers when incomplete tasks move forward. He hypothesizes that not living up to the ideal version of yourself is the source of this guilt. For this reason he uses paper for Daily Task Management and Weekly Planning to avoid inducing this guilt.

Another interesting thing about this article is that Curtis is basically leaving a commentary on another person’s article. This seems like a fairly painless way to generate content assuming your audience values what you have to say.

item.title: Here Is How I Use Tags üè∑Ô∏è And Links üîóÔ∏è In Obsidian To Manage My Zettelkasten üìùÔ∏è
item.description: Author: Bryan Jenks URL: Uses @ in front of people to identify that they are people Uses links instead of tags similarly to how I do. Perhaps I got this from him and forgot.
item.content:encoded:
Author: Bryan Jenks URL:

Uses @ in front of people to identify that they are people Uses links instead of tags similarly to how I do. Perhaps I got this from him and forgot. Uses empty files as tags because they visualize differently and can eventually help you figure out which MOCs should exist Uses links between Maps of Content to create an index. On each MOC he includes the parent to make traversal easier

item.title: How to review a book?
item.description: Attempt to summarize a book in a few sentences List the top 5 takeaways Are there people who would like this book? What parts of the book did I not agree with?

Are there people who would like this book?

What parts of the book did I not agree with?

References

item.title: 12 Life Lessons From 2021 - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
item.description: Metadata Author: Ali Abdaal Full Title: 12 Life Lessons From 2021 - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGmtNfrCgnvkprHmHXqDNKxNdvc Highlights Embrace the suck - Whenever I struggle with procrastination (eg writing my book), I lower the bar by telling myself that ‚ÄòI just need to write 500 crappy words for a crappy first draft of chapter three‚Äô.
item.content:encoded:
Metadata

  • Author: Ali Abdaal
  • Full Title: 12 Life Lessons From 2021 - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
  • URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGmtNfrCgnvkprHmHXqDNKxNdvc

Highlights

Embrace the suck - Whenever I struggle with procrastination (eg writing my book), I lower the bar by telling myself that ‚ÄòI just need to write 500 crappy words for a crappy first draft of chapter three‚Äô. Repeating ‚Äòcrappy‚Äô two times helps to neutralize my inner perfectionist. I always get more done that way, and I‚Äôm usually pleasantly surprised by the outcome. #review When you find yourself procrastinating, write a crappy first draft to help get started

item.title: 20 Ideas for Better Data Visualization by Taras Bakusevych Aug, 2021 UX Collective
item.description: Metadata Author: Taras Bakusevych Full Title: 20 Ideas for Better Data Visualization | by Taras Bakusevych | Aug, 2021 | UX Collective Category: URL: https://uxdesign.cc/20-ideas-for-better-data-visualization-73f7e3c2782d?cmdid=TMCZFEIK993AQ5 Highlights Label directly on the chart Without proper labeling, no matter how nice is your graph ‚Äî it won‚Äôt make sense.
item.content:encoded:
Metadata

  • Author: Taras Bakusevych
  • Full Title: 20 Ideas for Better Data Visualization | by Taras Bakusevych | Aug, 2021 | UX Collective
  • Category:
  • URL: https://uxdesign.cc/20-ideas-for-better-data-visualization-73f7e3c2782d?cmdid=TMCZFEIK993AQ5

Highlights

  1. Label directly on the chart Without proper labeling, no matter how nice is your graph ‚Äî it won‚Äôt make sense. Labeling directly on the chart is super helpful for all viewers. Consulting the legend requires time and mental energy to link the values and corresponding segments.

item.title: 2x2 Fave Games - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
item.description: Metadata Author: Shawn Blanc Full Title: 2x2: Fave Games - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGmthgmlJsLTgDvFRFNLSJWMSvc Highlights 1: Eliminate Small Decisions A small decision is something trivial: What to have for breakfast; what to wear; when to begin work; when to take your lunch break; etc.
item.content:encoded:
Metadata

  • Author: Shawn Blanc
  • Full Title: 2x2: Fave Games - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
  • URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGmthgmlJsLTgDvFRFNLSJWMSvc

Highlights

1: Eliminate Small Decisions A small decision is something trivial: What to have for breakfast; what to wear; when to begin work; when to take your lunch break; etc. Many of these small decisions can be automated and routinized by deciding in advance… thus, effectively removing them as unique decisions you make every single day. By automating your small decisions and eliminating them from your life, you can get back your much-needed energy to allow for a greater capacity to focus on the bigger decisions of your day-to-day life and the more challenging problems you are trying to solve. #review

item.title: 2x2 Five Steps for Making Progress on Your Goals - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
item.description: Metadata Author: Shawn Blanc Full Title: 2x2: Five Steps for Making Progress on Your Goals - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail Category: URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGlkjdkBfxChXflqGjvTKhsVzlg Highlights “When the most important things in our life happen we quite often do not know, at the moment, what is going on.
item.content:encoded:
Metadata

  • Author: Shawn Blanc
  • Full Title: 2x2: Five Steps for Making Progress on Your Goals - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
  • Category:
  • URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGlkjdkBfxChXflqGjvTKhsVzlg

Highlights

“When the most important things in our life happen we quite often do not know, at the moment, what is going on. A man does not always say to himself, ‘Hullo! I’m growing up’ It is often only when he looks back that he realises what has happened and recognises it as what people call ‘growing up.'” - C.S. Lewis

In Ray Dalio‚Äôs book, Principles, he lists a 5-step process for how to make progress on your goals: Identify your goals. Encounter your problems. Diagnose the problems to get to their root cause. Design changes to get around the problems. Do what is needed.

it reminded me of this quote from James Clear: “Highly focused people do not leave their options open. They make choices. If you commit to nothing, you‚Äôll be distracted by everything.”

item.title: 2x2 Improve Your Life Without Trying - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
item.description: Metadata Author: Create account Full Title: 2x2: Improve Your Life Without Trying - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGmvBtHDzcTHwJrcQSvwKNRVqKq Highlights 1: Alternative Ways to Spend 5 Minutes of Awkward Downtime Last week, as our latest Focus Academy cohort was wrapping up, one of the members asked in the Slack group about how to spend time during the ‚Äúdown moments‚Äù of his work day when there was roughly 5 or 10 minutes with nothing to do.
item.content:encoded:
Metadata

  • Author: Create account
  • Full Title: 2x2: Improve Your Life Without Trying - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
  • URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGmvBtHDzcTHwJrcQSvwKNRVqKq

Highlights

1: Alternative Ways to Spend 5 Minutes of Awkward Downtime Last week, as our latest Focus Academy cohort was wrapping up, one of the members asked in the Slack group about how to spend time during the ‚Äúdown moments‚Äù of his work day when there was roughly 5 or 10 minutes with nothing to do. Perhaps you‚Äôve experienced just such an awkward window of time like this ‚Äî such as in-between Zoom meetings or something. And so, allow me to suggest a few ways to spend those few minutes… If you Use Day One scroll through your Day One timeline and read a previous journal entry. Browse some old photos and memories. Launch Day One (or any other journal you have) and log how you‚Äôve spent your time so far for the day. Doing this for a few weeks can also be super helpful for getting a perspective of where your time and energy are being spent. Write down 3 new ideas. These could be articles you want to write, business ideas, places you want to visit or photograph, topics you want to research, date ideas for you and your spouse, gift ideas for a friend, etc. These ideas never have to to be acted on ‚Äî the point isn‚Äôt to generate a to-do list, but rather to exercise your mind. Ideation and creativity are muscles, and the more we exercise them the stronger they get. Send a text message to a friend or family member to tell them how awesome they are. Stand up and do some stretching / body movement. #review

item.title: 2x2 Lists, Lists, Lists.... - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
item.description: 2x2: Lists, Lists, Lists…. - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail Metadata Author: Create account Full Title: 2x2: Lists, Lists, Lists…. - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGmvTxVKczjwkdlWKjTnzhdKbbf Highlights I‚Äôve been using Day One as my journal app for about a decade.
item.content:encoded:
2x2: Lists, Lists, Lists…. - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail

Metadata

  • Author: Create account
  • Full Title: 2x2: Lists, Lists, Lists…. - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
  • URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGmvTxVKczjwkdlWKjTnzhdKbbf

Highlights

I‚Äôve been using Day One as my journal app for about a decade. And, there have certainly been times when I write and journal far less than I would like ‚Äî sometimes I just don‚Äôt have any interest or motivation to write in there. A new approach to journaling that I picked up about a month ago, is something that makes it very easy to create a Day One entry. And, more often than not, it leads me to continue writing. The approach is to simply finish this sentence: ‚ÄúToday was a good day because….‚Äù. #review

One type of goal is an attainment goal: something with a clear definition of completion that you achieve or accomplish. The other type is a Lifestyle Goal: a habit or routine that you incorporate into your everyday lifestyle. When setting a new goal in your life, knowing which type of goal can help you to succeed in getting to your desired outcome. #review

item.title: 2x2 The Law of Clarity - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
item.description: Metadata Author: Shawn Blanc Full Title: 2x2: The Law of Clarity - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail Category: URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGlkFrgzRNHMhzNKCwqkDLCdkdH Highlights 1: Time Blocks for Your Roles in Life I have a handful of roles in my life that are the most important to me right now: Husband, dad, friend, business owner, writer.
item.content:encoded:
Metadata

  • Author: Shawn Blanc
  • Full Title: 2x2: The Law of Clarity - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
  • Category:
  • URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGlkFrgzRNHMhzNKCwqkDLCdkdH

Highlights

1: Time Blocks for Your Roles in Life I have a handful of roles in my life that are the most important to me right now: Husband, dad, friend, business owner, writer. And I find that one of the best ways to consistently show up for these roles and maintain them as a priority in my life, is to have blocks of time set aside for them: date night, family dinner, friendship time, writing time, etc.

Priorities and GTD Showing Up

item.title: 2x2 Too Busy - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
item.description: Metadata Author: Shawn Blanc Full Title: 2x2: Too Busy? - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGmthprpNCxXhtdMSfDhsPGVsNz Highlights The best way to be strategic with how you are spending your time and energy is to be clear on your desired outcome, and then pick one thing you think will move you in that direction.
item.content:encoded:
Metadata

  • Author: Shawn Blanc
  • Full Title: 2x2: Too Busy? - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
  • URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGmthprpNCxXhtdMSfDhsPGVsNz

Highlights

The best way to be strategic with how you are spending your time and energy is to be clear on your desired outcome, and then pick one thing you think will move you in that direction. Stick with it for long enough to determine if your actions are working. If they are working, keep going. If they are not working, stop and try something new. #review

item.title: 3-2-1 A Quick Tip for Building Habits That Last, and the Connection Between Art and an Open Mind - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
item.description: Metadata Author: James Clear Full Title: 3-2-1: A Quick Tip for Building Habits That Last, and the Connection Between Art and an Open Mind - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail Category: URL: https://mail.
item.content:encoded:
Metadata

  • Author: James Clear
  • Full Title: 3-2-1: A Quick Tip for Building Habits That Last, and the Connection Between Art and an Open Mind - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
  • Category:
  • URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/1/#inbox/FMfcgzGkZkPKrJZjsfbjdqLfmNzfvHJH

Highlights

Theoretical physicist Richard Feynman with some advice for life: “Fall in love with some activity, and do it! Nobody ever figures out what life is all about, and it doesn’t matter. Explore the world. Nearly everything is really interesting if you go into it deeply enough. Work as hard and as much as you want to on the things you like to do the best. Don’t think about what you want to be, but what you want to do. Keep up some kind of a minimum with other things so that society doesn’t stop you from doing anything at all.”

“Different meanings can be assigned to the same events. Look for evidence of how the world is encouraging you, and you will find it. Look for evidence of how the world is burdening you, and you will find it. Choose an explanation that empowers you.”

“Spend more time searching for better information sources. A body filled with junk food struggles to move well. A mind filled with junk thoughts struggles to think well.”

“A quick and easy tip for building habits that last: Pick a standard time and place to do it. It‚Äôs easier to wake up knowing “I exercise at 4pm” than to decide each time when to fit a habit into your day. If it‚Äôs already decided, all you need to do is show up.”

item.title: 3-2-1 Active Patience, Focusing on What You Can Control, and Playing a Game Worth Winning - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
item.description: Metadata Author: James Clear Full Title: 3-2-1: Active Patience, Focusing on What You Can Control, and Playing a Game Worth Winning - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail Category: URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/#inbox/FMfcgzGllMNdBhpqBmJsNLxTwTSvNLSD Highlights Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius on focusing on what you can control: “You have power over your mind ‚Äî not outside events.
item.content:encoded:
Metadata

  • Author: James Clear
  • Full Title: 3-2-1: Active Patience, Focusing on What You Can Control, and Playing a Game Worth Winning - brandonkboswell@gmail.com - Gmail
  • Category:
  • URL: https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/#inbox/FMfcgzGllMNdBhpqBmJsNLxTwTSvNLSD

Highlights

Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius on focusing on what you can control: “You have power over your mind ‚Äî not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.”
